importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Pakistan launched the $37m GLOF-II project in 2017, which aimed to improve early warning systems for glacial lake outburst floods but failed to achieve real-time connectivity between human sensors and official rescue teams.
The World Bank reported that Pakistan’s mean temperature since the 1950s has risen by 1.3°C, twice the global average, highlighting the country’s extreme climate vulnerability.

The article was published on this date, providing a timely update on how Indigenous knowledge continues to play a vital role in climate resilience despite technological shortcomings in early warning systems.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: Between 2019 and 2022, Pakistan faced nearly 90 glacial lake outburst floods, illustrating the escalating frequency and severity of climate-related disasters in the region.
As climate change intensifies, northern Pakistan continues to face increasing risks from glacial melt and flash floods, making Indigenous knowledge an urgent and evolving solution.

keyTakeAways: Indigenous knowledge, including observation of weather patterns, animal behavior, and sound signals, is being used effectively by local shepherds in Gilgit-Baltistan to detect and warn of glacial lake outburst floods (GLOFs).

Despite significant government spending on early warning systems (EWS), including the $37 million GLOF-II project, there is widespread distrust among communities due to equipment malfunctions, lack of follow-up, and poor community engagement.

In incidents such as the one involving Wasiyat Khan and Mohammad Hussain, timely human intervention—using traditional signals like gunfire or fire—has successfully saved lives and prevented casualties, even when EWS systems fail.
The lack of trust in technological systems is compounded by allegations of officials falsely claiming credit for saved lives and by the absence of official investigations into EWS failures.
Pakistan, despite contributing less than 1% of global emissions, ranks among the top 10 most climate-vulnerable countries due to rising temperatures and glacial retreat in mountainous regions.

The effectiveness of Indigenous knowledge in early warning demonstrates that community-based, culturally grounded practices are essential components of climate resilience, especially in regions with limited technological infrastructure.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In northern Pakistan’s mountainous regions, particularly in Gilgit-Baltistan, Indigenous knowledge is proving essential in responding to glacial lake outburst floods (GLOFs) as technological early warning systems fail. Shepherds like Wasiyat Khan and Mohammad Hussain rely on traditional signs—such as sudden rainfall, animal behavior, and sound patterns—to detect disasters and activate community evacuations. Despite government investments, such as the $37 million GLOF-II project, there is widespread distrust in the systems due to malfunctioning equipment, lack of follow-up, and poor community engagement. These failures have led to a reliance on human-based warnings, where timely action by local residents has saved lives. The article highlights Pakistan’s status as one of the world’s most climate-vulnerable countries, with rising temperatures accelerating glacier melt and flood risks. It underscores the urgent need to integrate traditional Indigenous knowledge into official disaster response frameworks, as a more culturally grounded, effective, and trusted system for climate resilience.
title: How Indigenous knowledge is aiding Pakistan’s fight against climate change
